Story Overview.question: Does the story idea have the force it will need to lead to
Are you the right person to tell this story? Do you believe in it?

Is your concept posed in the form of a story question? In Larry Brooks' definition, a concept is an idea that asks a question that implies conflict. An idea is just an idea; a concept is the seed of a story. Spend time fleshing out your concept.
Do you understand the story type, it's lengths, intended effect, and potential markets?

Have you given sufficient thought to Viewpoint? Point of view is the most important single structural decision of your story, the voice through which you tell your tale. Not only person, but tense, tone (ironic, bitter, etc), reliability, the POV character's sophistication or naivity- endless variations are possible. POV choice should be made early, as it can affect every scene in your story.
Who is your audience? Who are you telling your story to?
Do you know, or are you prepared to learn, something about the subject?
What is your aim? What are you trying to accomplish?
What form will your story take? (Play, novel, short story, etc.) Are you familiar with this form?

Setting.question: Is the setting clear in terms of time and location?
Does the setting appeal to the senses? Does it appeal to all of the senses, and not just sight?
Does this setting create mood and atmosphere appropriate to the scenes being portrayed here?

Problem.question: Is the struggle between opposing forces clearly recognizable? If the story is one of man against himself (internal conflict), your protagonist must be his own antagonist. If society or nature is the opponent, is it squarely against the protagonist's goal?
What does your protagonist have at stake? What goal or desire matters more to him than anything? What drives this person?
Your audience should usually empathize with your protagonist. Which qualities will gain the empathy or sympathy of the audience?
Character, as well as plot, can create conflict. Does the protagonist have traits which contrast and oppose traits of the antagonist?
Your protagonist should be capable of growth and change. Which trait, belief or habit is the weakness, or contains the contradiction, that this person must change? This is his 'inner problem.'
What does your antagonist have at stake? What goal or desire matters more to him than anything? What drives this person?

Is your antagonist a worthy opponent? Does he believe in his own goal? Is he forced to behave as he does? Does he have sufficient will and drive? Are the protagonist and the antagonist evenly matched?
How would you describe the relationship between the protagonist and the antagonist? Will it change during the course of the story?
What does the character have at stake? What is his purpose or desire? What is he willing to do to achieve it? What motivates him?
What is your problem's premise? Can you summarize the problem?
What is your problem's theme? What are you setting out to prove? What does it all mean?
Do you know which is your main or story problem? When that problem is resolved, the story's over.
Can you visualize your problem's resolution as a scene? Does it match your premise?
Do you protagonist and antagonist have traits and values which support your premise?

Plot Point.question: Are there scene templates (MasterPlots) for scenes to use under a Problem? Have you used the MasterPlots tool?
Are there Dramatic Situations which can provide a Plot Point (or Problem) relevant to the story?
Are there set pieces (Stock Scenes) which the reader will expect in a story of this type? Have you considered the Stock Scenes tool?
Does this scene follow causally from the preceeding scene?

Are you plotting for dramatic tension? Are you: taking your time resuming interrupted scenes? Leaving uncertainty as to motives, comments, or actions? Stretching out or prolonging successful outcomes? Offering poor choices and incomplete resolutions in scenes? Using a deadline or 'ticking clock'? Varying scene length and/or type?
What future conflict or story events should you foreshadow in this scene?

Should you plan to tell the current plot point as a scene, or as foreshortened prose (narrative summary)? Scenes are generally preferable; they're more visual and dramatic, and follow the 'show, don't tell' dictim. Foreshortened prose provides lots of information and compresses action, time or space, but is easier for the reader to ignore.

Is your scene securely anchored with a setting, and/or with physical objects for your characters to handle (props)? Do the setting, time, and props contribute to the scene's mood and emotional impact?
What's the purpose of this scene? Does it belong in the story? Does it belong at this location in the story (referring to its Narrative View placement)?
Every scene must 'move the needle.' What changes for your scene's protagonist? For the story's protagonist?

What is the protagonist trying to accomplish in this scene? What's his goal? How does it relate to the story or prolem goal? What's the opposition? What's the antagonist trying to accomplish? Have you used GMC (Goal, Motivation, Conflict) to develop this scene?

Does the outcome of the current scene lead to the next? If the outcome is the protagonist's failure to obtain his goal, what will he try next? If the outcome is success, what new twist or problem will be introduced?

Does the outcome of the current scene serve your objectives for this section of the story? (For example, if in the middle story (complications), the outcome of the scene should leave the protagonist further from his story goal than he was at the start of the scene.) Are you: Establishing the situation? Developing conflict? At crisis? Note: ask this of Problems (for sequences) as well as scenes?
What emotions motivate the protagonist at this point? What does he feel?
What happens next? What if...?
What's at stake? Can the stakes be increased?
Where are all of your characters right now? What are they doing? What's going on off stage?
Does the story start at the right place (During the crisis? Just before the crisis? After the crisis?)
(Beginning:) Is there a narrative hook? Does the story grab the reader's interest from the beginning?
(Beginning:) Do the opening scenes introduce the protagonist? The antagonist? Are all characters in the opening significant?
(Beginning:) Does the beginning introduce the story problem or premise? Is there an expectation of change?
(Beginning:) Does the beginning provide an initial conflict?
(Ending) Does the ending answer the story question?
(Ending:) Are the important story threads wrapped up? Is there dramatic tension which was not released? Should it have been?
(Ending:) Is the ending emotional? Is there catharsis?
How does the scene begin?
How will the scene end?
What is the protagonist's attitude during the scene? How does he feel?
What is the antagonist's attitude during the scene? How does he feel?

Character.question: What is the character's role in the story? Does the character fit the role? If not, which will you change: the story or the character?
Is your character fleshed out? Does she have the dimensionality of a real person, with physical, social, and psychological qualities? Can you visualize her?
Does your character have character traits which are central to her outlook and behavior- which define her character?
What is there about this character that will make the reader or audience care about him? What will gain the reader's sympathy or animosity?

What is there about the character which will create or sustain conflict? The character's motivation? His purpose or desire? A trait which needs altering? A trait which contrasts with a trait in another character?
Does your character have both good and bad qualities? What facets of this character contradict other facets?
What story situations might provoke the protagonist (or antagonist) to extreme measures or acts? How will she react in crisis?
How does your character feel about the other characters? What is their relationship?
Are your character's traits consistent with his background, as cause and/or effect?

Is your cast too large, or too small? Will introducing or eliminating characters make a more effective story? If you need to eliminate a role, have you considered combining several characters into one?

scenes.name: Three Act Play
scenes.notes: An act is a dramatic unit consisting of a number of scenes. On the stage acts may be separated by a curtain fall; TV show acts often end with a commercial or station break. The acts in Three Act Play are also dramatic units comprised of scenes, but the acts are logical, rather than physical, groupings. The first act sets up the problem to be solved. The second act, the rising action, has the protagonist seek to solve his problem and achieve his goal, but he runs into obstacles, or reversals. These problems add dramatic tension. The third and final act resolves the problem from the first act.

scenes.name: Narrative hook
scenes.notes: It's important to capture the reader's interest at the beginning of the story sufficiently to keep him reading until the story itself- the protagonist and the problem have engaged his attention. The opening paragraphs of the story must serve as an advertisement that it's worth reading.

scenes.name: Introduce Characters
scenes.notes: Be careful to introduce only the major characters (protagonist, antagonist, love interest, etc.) in the opening scenes. Readers are familiar with this, and will expect any character introduced early to be significant.

scenes.name: Present Problem to be Solved
scenes.notes: The first act should conclude with the protagonist's goal clearly before her and with her committed to obtaining it.

scenes.name: Act II -  Rising Action
scenes.notes: The second act is, simply, the middle part which connects Act I (the question) with Act III (the answer.)  If the story problem is too easily solved,  there's nothing to entertain the reader. Therefore the rising action consists of one or more obstacles which prevent the protagonist from obtaining his story goal. Providing the obstacle is the the job of the antagonist. The number of obstacles depends on the story form.

scenes.name: First Obstacle
scenes.notes: Every obstacle contains two parts. First, the protagonist pursues his story goal. He devises a plan and takes action which will move him toward that goal. If there has been a previous obstacle, the protagonist's immediate goal may be to respond to it, but he works toward the ultimate goal. Second, an obstacle or reversal usually happens to thwart the goal. If the protagonist's immediate step ends in success, it's only temporary; in Act II he must always end up further from his goal than ever.

scenes.name: Subsequent Obstacles
scenes.notes: (See notes for First Obstacle)

scenes.name: Turning Point
scenes.notes: The reversals may cause an emotional change in the characters. This change is the recognition that things have gone too far to ever go back to the way they were before the story. The story has forever changed the characters or their relationships. This recognition usually occurs at the end of the second act, just before the climax.

scenes.name: Climax
scenes.notes: This is the point in which the story problem is solved, one way or another. Either the protagonist succeeds in obtaining her goal, or she fails, or she decides that the goal isn't worth obtaining any more, or she discovers something that changes the situation- usually =something about herself. It's important that your protagonist takes her fate in her own hands and solve, or try to solve, her own problem. Having the calvary ride up at the last minute is no longer acceptable.

scenes.name: Denouement
scenes.notes: 'Denouement' is from the French for 'an untying'. In the denouement, all of the knotty problems posed by the story are unravelled. Any remaining mysteries are answered, any remaining complications solved, so that things are neatly wrapped up. This plot point may be omitted in many stories, depending on your preferences.

beatSheets.name: Three Act Play
beatSheets.notes: The oldest plot pattern, from Aristotle. The plot consists of three movements, or acts. The first act, or setup, presents us with a problem that must be solved. The second act, or rising action, presents obstacles as the protagonist tries to solve the problem. The third act contains the logical outcome of the events in the first two acts. Most stories can be cast as a Three Act Play, and most of the other Masterplots are embellishments of Aristotle's idea of plot structure.

scenes.notes: An optional prolog, since the Hook is often a point of weakness. It's used before the conflict is introduced, to grab your Reader's attention.

scenes.name: Plot Turn I (4)
scenes.notes: Move from the hook to Midpoint. Introduce the conflict. New people, new secrets. Follow the white rabbit. Call to adventure.

scenes.notes: Apply pessure. Something goes wrong. Peace is destroyed. Bad guys attack. Introduce the villain.

scenes.name: Midpoint (3)
scenes.notes: Protagonist moves from reaction to action. This is the Mirror Moment- character is forced to look at himself.

scenes.notes: Apply more pressure, until the situation seems hopeless. The bad guys seem to win. These are the jaws of defeat from which your hero snatches victory. Make sure the teeth are sharp.

scenes.notes: Move the story from midpoint to the end. You optain the thing you need to win- even if you don't realize it. 'The power is in you.'

scenes.name: Resolution (1)
scenes.notes: Not the falling action, but the climax. A disaster/bad ending for many middle story problems. Or a solution may lead to a subsequent problem. The major story problem resolution ends story.

beatSheets.name: Seven Point Story Structure
beatSheets.notes: Dan Wells is a bestselling author and game developer. His popular 'seven point' plot method is described on a series of YouTube videos and blog posts and has been widely reposted and referenced on the web. The numbers in the plot points are the suggested order in which the scenes should be outlined.

scenes.name: Opening Image (0-1%)
scenes.notes: The story begins by painting a picture of the protagonist's world before the adventure starts. This scene sets the tone, mood, and style of the story, offering a glimpse into the protagonist's current state of mind and foreshadowing her story arc.

scenes.name: Theme Stated: 5%
scenes.notes: This beat typically occurs early in the story. A character, often not the main protagonist, states the theme or central message of the story, usually in a way that the protagonist doesn't fully grasp yet.

scenes.name: Setup: 1-10%
scenes.notes: This section introduces the protagonist's world in more detail, revealing their daily life, relationships, and any existing problems. It establishes the status quo and often hints at the protagonist's flaws or areas for growth. Supporting characters are introduced, and the stage is set for the upcoming adventure.

scenes.name: Catalyst: 10%
scenes.notes: Also known as the inciting incident. A significant event disrupts the protagonist's world. This forces the character out of their comfort zone and sets the main story in motion. It could be a breakup, a death, an invitation, or any event that significantly alters the protagonist's course.

scenes.name: Debate: 10-20%
scenes.notes: Following the catalyst, the protagonist struggles with the decision to act. This is often an internal struggle where they question whether to accept the call to adventure. The character may resist change, longing for things to return to normal. Sometimes, a friend or mentor offers advice that the protagonist initially resists. This beat is similar to but less direct than the Refusal of the Call in the Hero's Journey.

scenes.name: Break into Two: 20%
scenes.notes: This marks the end of Act I and the beginning of Act II. The protagonist makes the choice to embark on their journey or face the challenge presented. They commit to a new goal or course of action, even if the path ahead is uncertain and fraught with obstacles.

scenes.name: B Story: 22%
scenes.notes: This beat typically introduces a secondary storyline, often involving a new relationship or character that will play a crucial role in the protagonist's journey.

scenes.name: Fun and Games: 20-50%
scenes.notes: This beat usually comprises the first half of Act II. It's where the premise of the story is explored, and the protagonist faces various challenges and obstacles related to their new goal.

scenes.name: Midpoint: 50%
scenes.notes: The midpoint marks a significant turning point in the story. It often involves a major event that raises the stakes and changes the direction of the narrative.

scenes.name: Bad Guys Close In: 50-75%
scenes.notes: The antagonistic forces (which could be literal bad guys, internal conflicts, or challenging circumstances) gain ground. The protagonist faces increasing pressure and obstacles as they approach the climax of the story.

scenes.name: All Is Lost: 75%
scenes.notes: At this point in the story, the protagonist experiences a major setback or loss. It's their lowest moment, where everything seems to have fallen apart. This beat represents the greatest challenge to the protagonist's goal or mission.

scenes.name: Dark Night of the Soul: 75-80%
scenes.notes: Following the "All Is Lost" moment, the protagonist enters a period of deep reflection. This beat shows how the character has changed throughout the story and often involves a realization of the theme. It's a moment of introspection where the protagonist may finally learn their lesson or understand what truly matters.

scenes.name: Break into Three: 80%
scenes.notes: This beat marks the beginning of Act III. The protagonist experiences an epiphany, finally realizing what they must do to resolve their situation. Symbolically, they are reborn as an improved version of themselves, armed with resolve and new self-awareness.

scenes.name: Finale: 80-99%
scenes.notes: The finale is where the protagonist faces the main conflict head-on, armed with the lessons and growth they've experienced throughout the story. This climactic sequence showcases the protagonist's transformation and resolution of the central conflict.

scenes.name: Final Image: 99-100%
scenes.notes: The story concludes with a scene that mirrors or contrasts with the opening image. This final snapshot demonstrates how much the protagonist and their world have changed as a result of the journey, bringing the story full circle.

beatSheets.name: Save The Cat
beatSheets.notes: Save the Cat is a popular story structure template created by screenwriter Blake Snyder. It consists of 15 key plot points (or "beats") that help writers craft engaging and well-paced stories. This structure can be applied to novels, screenplays, and other narrative forms. The percentages indicate approximately where (by wordcount) in the  narrative each beat should take place.

scenes.name: Recognition of Goal (A)
scenes.notes:
A strong character finds herself in a bad situation with a
worthwhile goal and a good reason for achieving it.

scenes.name: Initial Barrier (B)
scenes.notes: The protagonist encounters a major obstacle.

scenes.name: Low Point (C)
scenes.notes:
This is the protagonist's initial reaction to the barrier,
and an emotional low point.

scenes.name: Barrier Reversal (D)
scenes.notes: The protagonist overcomes the initial barrier by his or own actions.

scenes.name: High Point (E)
scenes.notes: The protagonist nearly reaches the goal.

scenes.name: Rug Pull (F)
scenes.notes: A disaster, major reversal or much greater obstacle arises and stands between the protagonist and the goal. This is related to a flaw in the protagonist.

scenes.name: Catastrophe (G)
scenes.notes: All seems lost.

scenes.name: Struggle (H)
scenes.notes: The protagonist overcomes the second obstacle, growing the process.

scenes.name: Achievement of Goal (I)
scenes.notes: The protagonist achieves the goal, using what he's learned from, or based on how he's changed from, the story events.

beatSheets.name: W-Diagram
beatSheets.notes: This version of the W-Diagram is taught by Janice Bennet in her writing workshops. See Kubis & Howland in the bibliography for more information. Picture a letter W. The plot points in this masterplot are the vertices and edges of the 'W', starting with the top left. The edges or legs represent rising or falling dramatic tension; the two low vertices are the places where things are worse for the protagonist. Every point except for the two end points is a 'turning point' in the plot. A longer story form can have multiple W-diagrams. For a tragedy, invert the diagram to make an 'M'.

scenes.name: Ordinary World
scenes.notes: This plot point shows the protagonist in his customary, normal environment, before he is thrust into the special and alien environment of the story.

scenes.name: Call to Adventure
scenes.notes: The protagonist is presented with his goal: a problem to solve, an adventure to take, or a challenge to rise to.

scenes.name: Refusal of the Call
scenes.notes: The protagonist shows reluctance or fear to begin the journey. This is largely fear of unknown.

scenes.name: Mentor
scenes.notes: The protagonist allies with a wise and trusted advisor or teacher. The mentor's role is to prepare the protagonist for the journey. However, the protagonist must eventually face the challenge alone.

scenes.name: First Threshold
scenes.notes: The protagonist is now committed to the journey. In Quest stories this is the start of the travels; in other stories the First Threshold may be an act of challenge or defiance.

scenes.name: Tests, Allies, and Enemies
scenes.notes: These are the beginning of the middle story (Act II in Three Act Play.)  The protagonist's courage and determination are tested in a series of confrontations. These tests allow the protagonist to grow, learn, and acquire information.

scenes.name: Approach to the Inmost Cave
scenes.notes: The protagonist approaches the place where the object of the quest is hidden. This is dangerous ground, often the territory of the antagonist. To approach the goal, the protagonist must overcome the obstacles of this second major threshold.

scenes.name: Supreme Ordeal
scenes.notes: The protagonist directly confronts his greatest fear. Here he may loose his life or his soul, and the outcome is in the balance.

scenes.name: Seizing the Reward
scenes.notes: The protagonist takes possession of the goal he has sought. The reward may be an object, some knowledge, or the end of a conflict with someone (as with romances.)

scenes.name: The Road Back
scenes.notes: This is the beginning of Act II in the Three Act Play. The action isn't over yet; the forces the protagonist confronted in the Supreme Ordeal may rise again and pursue him. The protagonist begins his attempt to return to the Ordinary World.

scenes.name: Resurrection
scenes.notes: This is the second major test of the protagonist, often almost a replay of the Supreme Ordeal. It represents a moment of renewal, which wins the protagonist new power, or which proves his growth as a result of what when before.

scenes.name: Return With The Elixir
scenes.notes: The protagonist returns to the Ordinary World. A new equilibrium is restored, but things are different than they were at the start of the story, because the protagonist has brought back some treasure or knowledge from the journey.

beatSheets.name: Hero's Journey
beatSheets.notes: The Hero's Journey is described in Joseph Campbell's 'The Hero with a Thousand Faces.' It's a distillation of the hero legend as it occurs through the ages in many cultures. The Hero's Journey taps into the deep roots of storytelling. In this Masterplot, every story is a quest, whether an outward journey or an inward one. The stages of the journey are a framework to the inward growth and understanding that mirrors the journey itself. This dual quest is the basis of the deep symbolism and the universal appeal of these story elements. The stages of the Journey can be used in any story, and can be combined with any other masterplot.

scenes.name: Introduction
scenes.notes: Establish the subplot or complication, introducing key characters or the central issue.

scenes.name: Development
scenes.notes: Expand on the subplot or complication, showing its relevance to the main story or characters.

scenes.name: First Attempt
scenes.notes: Characters make an initial effort to address the subplot issue or overcome the complication.

scenes.name: Complication
scenes.notes: Introduce new obstacles or raise the stakes, making the subplot or complication more challenging.

scenes.name: Escalation
scenes.notes: Increase tension or difficulty, potentially intertwining the subplot more closely with the main plot.

scenes.name: Pivot
scenes.notes: A turning point where characters gain new insight or change their approach to the subplot or complication.

scenes.name: Climax
scenes.notes: The highest point of tension in the subplot, often coinciding with or supporting the main plot's climax.

scenes.name: Resolution
scenes.notes: Wrap up the subplot or complication, showing its impact on characters or the overall story.

beatSheets.name: Subplot/Complication Beat Sheet (Mini)
beatSheets.notes:
This beat sheet is designed to help writers structure subplots and complications within a larger narrative. It provides a flexible framework that can be adapted to various story lengths and complexities. This structure can be used for secondary character arcs, thematic explorations, or smaller obstacles that enrich the main plot. To use this beat sheet effectively:
Identify your subplot or complication and its relationship to the main plot. Outline each beat, considering how it connects to your overall story. Ensure that the subplot or complication enhances rather than detracts from the main narrative. Adjust the scale of each beat based on your story's needs – some may be brief scenes, while others could span multiple chapters. Consider how the resolution of the subplot or complication will impact your main story or character development.

scenes.name: Opening Image
scenes.notes: The story begins by painting a picture of the protagonist's world before the adventure starts. This scene sets the tone, mood, and style of the story, offering a glimpse into the protagonist's current state of mind and foreshadowing her story arc.

scenes.name: Setup
scenes.notes: This section introduces the protagonist's world in more detail, revealing their daily life, relationships, and any existing problems. It establishes the status quo and often hints at the protagonist's flaws or areas for growth. Supporting characters are introduced, and the stage is set for the upcoming adventure.

scenes.name: Catalyst
scenes.notes: Also known as the inciting incident. A significant event disrupts the protagonist's world. This forces the character out of their comfort zone and sets the main story in motion. It could be a breakup, a death, an invitation, or any event that significantly alters the protagonist's course.

scenes.name: Break into Two
scenes.notes: This marks the end of Act I and the beginning of Act II. The protagonist makes the choice to embark on their journey or face the challenge presented. They commit to a new goal or course of action, even if the path ahead is uncertain and fraught with obstacles.

scenes.name: Midpoint
scenes.notes: The midpoint marks a significant turning point in the story. It often involves a major event that raises the stakes and changes the direction of the narrative.

scenes.name: Bad Guys Close In: 50-75%
scenes.notes: The antagonistic forces (which could be literal bad guys, internal conflicts, or challenging circumstances) gain ground. The protagonist faces increasing pressure and obstacles as they approach the climax of the story.

scenes.name: All Is Lost
scenes.notes: At this point in the story, the protagonist experiences a major setback or loss. It's their lowest moment, where everything seems to have fallen apart. This beat represents the greatest challenge to the protagonist's goal or mission.

scenes.name: Final Image
scenes.notes: The story concludes with a scene that mirrors or contrasts with the opening image. This final snapshot demonstrates how much the protagonist and their world have changed as a result of the journey, bringing the subplot full circle.

beatSheets.name: Save The Cat (Mini)
beatSheets.notes: This is a simplified beatsheet based on the Save the Cat beatsheet created by screenwriter Blake Snyder. It focuses on the most crucial elements, making it more suitable for subplots and complications. The percentages indicate approximately where (by wordcount) in the  narrative each beat should take place.

scenes.name: Starting Point/Flaw
scenes.notes: The problem begins by painting a picture of the protagonist's world before the adventure starts. This establishes the character's initial state, including their false beliefs, weaknesses, or unfulfilled needs.

scenes.name: Inciting Incident
scenes.notes: An event occurs that challenges the character's beliefs or exposes their flaw.

scenes.name: Resistance to Change
scenes.notes: The character clings to their old ways or beliefs, often making things worse.

scenes.name: Glimpse of Potential
scenes.notes: A moment where the character sees a possible better version of themselves.

scenes.name: Setback/Retreat
scenes.notes: The character faces a challenge and retreats to their old behaviors.

scenes.name: Crisis of Faith
scenes.notes: A major event forces the character to confront their false beliefs or flaws.

scenes.name: Self-Revelation
scenes.notes: Your character has an epiphany about their false beliefs and realizes the need for change.

scenes.name: Growth/Change
scenes.notes: The character takes action based on their new understanding. This is usually where Character Arc ties back to its external problem.

scenes.name: New Equilibrium
scenes.notes: The character's new state after the Growth/Change internal transformation.

beatSheets.name: Character Arc (Mini)
beatSheets.notes: The Character Arc beat sheet is primarily focused on the internal journey and transformation of a character, rather than external plot events. It focuses on the internal struggle and transformation of the character, showing how they overcome their flaws, false beliefs, or emotional wounds. It's designed to track the character's psychological and emotional journey rather than external plot events. It's worth noting that this internal arc often intertwines with the external plot, with the character's inner journey influencing their actions and decisions in the main storyline. The goal is to ensure that your protagonist undergoes meaningful growth and change throughout the story.

scenes.name: Introduction of Love Interest
scenes.notes: The potential romantic partner is introduced to the protagonist or reader.

scenes.name: First Interaction
scenes.notes: The first meaningful exchange between the protagonist and love interest.

scenes.name: Growing Attraction
scenes.notes: Moments that show increasing interest or chemistry between the characters.

scenes.name: Obstacles Emerge
scenes.notes: Conflicts or issues arise that complicate the potential relationship.

scenes.name: Deepening Connection
scenes.notes: Despite obstacles, the characters grow closer or understand each other better.

scenes.name: Setback or Conflict
scenes.notes: A major event threatens the budding relationship.

scenes.name: Realization of Feelings
scenes.notes: One or both characters acknowledge their romantic feelings.

scenes.name: Climactic Moment
scenes.notes: A pivotal scene where the characters must confront their feelings or situation.

scenes.name: Resolution
scenes.notes: The subplot is resolved, either with the characters getting together or deciding to part ways.

beatSheets.name: Romantic Subplot Beat Sheet (Mini)
beatSheets.notes: A romantic subplot beat sheet typically outlines the key moments and progression of a secondary romantic storyline within a larger narrative. These beats would typically be interspersed throughout the main plot, complementing and sometimes intersecting with the primary storyline. The exact structure and timing of these beats can vary depending on the specific story and how prominent the romantic subplot is meant to be.

scenes.name: Custom Beat
scenes.notes: This is a placeholder for your custom beat. You can define the specific action, event, or moment that is crucial to your story. Describe what happens in this beat and how it contributes to the overall narrative.

beatSheets.name: Custom Beat Sheet
beatSheets.notes: This is a custom beat sheet that can be used to outline any story, subplot, or complication. It allows you to define your own beats and structure based on your specific narrative needs. You can add, remove, or modify beats as necessary to fit your story.

subTopics.name: Alternate history
subTopics.notes: A past event, such as a battle, is given a different outcome. The story evolves from that premise.

subTopics.name: Cyberpunk
subTopics.notes: Near future stories which stress gritty, dysfunctional societies and advanced computer, electronic, and biological devices.

subTopics.name: Hard science fiction
subTopics.notes: Based upon exact and logical extrapolation from real science.

subTopics.name: Military science fiction
subTopics.notes: Future warfare, often involving space or other worlds. Stresses military organization, strategy, tactics.

subTopics.name: Science fantasy
subTopics.notes: Mixes magical or fantastic elements with SF milieus.

subTopics.name: Sociological science fiction
subTopics.notes: Character oriented stories which deal with extrapolations of social environment- religious, cultural, ethnic or gender related, economic, political. Utopian and dystopian stories often fit in this subgenre.

subTopics.name: Space opera
subTopics.notes: Plot oriented stories which stress adventure, large and sweeping settings, etc.

subTopics.name: Young adult
subTopics.notes: Science fiction stories aimed at the YA market- shorter books, young leading characters.

subTopics.name: Category Romance
subTopics.notes: Category romances are short, contemporary novels. They follow a 'romance formula' plot: girl meets boy; love blooms; obstacles tear lovers apart; lovers reunite, solve their problems, and commit to each other, usually to marriage.

subTopics.name: Historical Romance
subTopics.notes: Often longer novels. Set in any time period prior to WWI. The emphasis is on the romance, but historical accuracy is necessary.

subTopics.name: Contemporary Romance
subTopics.notes: Present day settings, and realistic characters. Emphasis on problems readers can identify with.

subTopics.name: Regency Romance
subTopics.notes: Shorter works, set during the Regency period (1811-20), in England. Emphasis on wit and light tone. Lesser sexual emphasis than other historical romances.

subTopics.name: Romantic Suspense/Gothic
subTopics.notes: Suspense plots are built around a mystery, but interwoven with romance. Contemporary backgrounds. Gothics rely on elements of horror and mood; often have a supernatural element.

subTopics.name: Science Fiction/Fantasy
subTopics.notes: As with SF&F genre novels, emphasis on milieu. Love stories placed in other worlds, futuristic settings. Time travel stories, with one of the lovers from a different time, are a popular form.

subTopics.name: Ghosts
subTopics.notes: The soul of a dead person, moving among the living. Usually haunts one location. May be out for vengeance, or may be a figure of pity or aid.

subTopics.name: Werewolves
subTopics.notes: A person who assumes the shape of a wolf or other creature. See the 'Metamorphosis' master plot. The werewolf, when in human guise, often seeks to escape the curse.

subTopics.name: Vampires
subTopics.notes: Modern vampires and were-creatures may be the result of genetic engineering, nanotechnology, etc. Vampires range from the horrific to the camp.

subTopics.name: Rejuvenation and Immortality
subTopics.notes: Frequently in the form of the 'mad scientist' story. The quest for immortality is often treated as forbidden knowledge, for which the seeker must be punished.

subTopics.name: Reincarnation
subTopics.notes: Another variation of the 'Metamorphosis' master plot.

subTopics.name: Paranormal forces
subTopics.notes: One common variation has paranormal forces as manifestations of a satanic or evil presence or possession. Another shows ordinary persons who acquire these abilities and are corrupted by the power.

subTopics.name: Satan and Demonic Forces
subTopics.notes: The ultimate villain. The complications will either be direct force and violence or Faustian attempts to lure the protagonist with knowledge, power, or wealth.

subTopics.name: Voodoo and the Undead
subTopics.notes: Similar to the Witchcraft and Devil Worship milieus, but with emphasis on West Indian voodoo rites, zombies, etc. These stories often emphasize the spectacular tropical locales.

subTopics.name: Witchcraft and Devil Worship
subTopics.notes: Similar to Satan and Demonic Forces, but the antagonists humans who practice arcane and dark arts. Because the forces on each side are more evenly matched, trickery and guile are frequently used complications.

subTopics.name: Splatterpunk
subTopics.notes: Particularly graphic, gory horror stories. Splatterpunk is a subgenre with its own following.

subTopics.name: Fairies, Elves, etc.
subTopics.notes: Not the nice little creatures who bake cookies. Often represent an older, and dying, fantastic world. Gifts from these creatures are often not benevolent. These creatures are frequently depicted as luring children away.

subTopics.name: Mythic Gods
subTopics.notes: Some of the gods are from older and actual religions, such as Norse Greek mythology. In other cases the mythos is created entirely from the writer's imagination, such as Lovecraft's Necronomicon.

subTopics.name: Immortality
subTopics.notes: The quest for Immortality is the oldest (from the story of Gilgamesh) example of Knowledge Men are Not Meant to Have. These stories frequently cast the questor as Mad Scientist antagonists. They are also the subject of high tragedy.

subTopics.name: The Crime Itself
subTopics.notes: What crime was committed?  Murder?  Arson?  Robbery?

subTopics.name: Scene of the Crime
subTopics.notes: Where was the crime committed?  When?  What weapons were used?  What tactics?  The time relates to alibis. The locale must provide access for the perpetrator.

subTopics.name: The Victim
subTopics.notes: Who is the victim?  In order to allow multiple suspects, it often helps if the victim is easy to dislike.

subTopics.name: The Criminal
subTopics.notes: Who did the deed?  What is his motive?

subTopics.name: The Detective
subTopics.notes: Usually the protagonist. Often the viewpoint character, although the detective's sidekick is often the VP character. How does she become involved?

subTopics.name: The Suspects
subTopics.notes: Each suspect needs his own motive for committing the crime.

subTopics.name: Other Characters
subTopics.notes: Often needed to flesh out the roles of the suspects. The real criminal may, or may not, be an initial suspect.

subTopics.name: Clues
subTopics.notes: Any evidence the investigation will produce, and its significance. Clues will be plants, some as red herrings, some as pointers to the solution.

subTopics.name: The Solution
subTopics.notes: How does the sleuth solve the case?  What is the turning point?  A secret discovered, the significance of a clue made known, a slip by the criminal, a bluff?

subTopics.name: =Frontier and Civilization
subTopics.notes: Contrasting the cities and laws of the East with the barren and lawless frontier provides the substance of the classic Hero's Journey.

subTopics.name: Self Reliance
subTopics.notes: The protagonist has to make do, to stand and deliver, in order to achieve his goal. He can't trust on others (particularly the law) in the uncivilized wilderness. These stories emphasize the growth of the protagonist.

subTopics.name: The Showdown
subTopics.notes: The classic confrontation between protagonist and antagonist. Variations often exploit the subtheme that inexperienced but good townspeople can band together to defeat experienced villains. Another variation uses the (reluctant) aid of an experienced gunman, a ShapeShifter.

subTopics.name: Land Greed
subTopics.notes: Land was the Grail that lured many men westward, and greed for land was the catalyst for many a real confrontation. Land is often used as a McGuffin, a force to start the confrontation.

subTopics.name: General Remarks
subTopics.notes: Fantasy stories are marked by more imaginative situations and characters than 'realistic' fiction. This emphasis on imagination sometimes makes boundaries between fantasy and science fiction or horror difficult to define. Fantasy may combine elements of other genres with one or more of the following.

subTopics.name: Fantasy Quest
subTopics.notes: A quest story (see Quest master plot.)  The hero is from the 'real', contemporary world, but is drawn into a fantastic world in which he assumes the role of hero.

subTopics.name: Magic Realism
subTopics.notes: An otherwise contemporary world in which magic is treated as an ordinary occupance, more or less like any form of engineering or science.

subTopics.name: Ring Trilogy Homages
subTopics.notes: Rehashes of Tolkien's works.

subTopics.name: Return of the King
subTopics.notes: The hero is the true heir to a kingdom. Frequently he was secreted away, at birth, for his safety's sake. He becomes aware of the true facts and acts to regain his throne.

subTopics.name: Sword and sorcery
subTopics.notes: This fantasy milieu contains elements of Middle Ages weaponry and combat, such as the bow and arrow and the sword (although other weapons technology may be present.)  Magic, often black magic, is practiced by a select few. These stories often pit a warrior against dark and powerful magical adversaries. If the warrior has magical powers, they seem slight, until their true significance is revealed.

subTopics.name: Traditional Fantasy
subTopics.notes: The fantasy world is inhabited by beings from folk tales- Elves, dwarves, ogres, etc. Humans may or may not be present. The fantastic inhabitants may exhibit any range of good or bad characteristics, but are recognizably human-like in motive and emotion.

subTopics.name: Children's Fantasy
subTopics.notes: Any of the previous fantasy stories, but usually light upbeat, in which the protagonist is a child or young person.

subTopics.name: Alien contact
subTopics.notes: Includes invasion stories and voyages of Terrans to other worlds. The alien may also be a man metamorphosized mentally or physically into something different. 'First contact' stories are often used to explore sociological ideas.

subTopics.name: Alternate time track
subTopics.notes: Asks what would have happened if, at some critical historical juncture events took a different path- if the Axis powers had won WWII, or the south had won the civil war, for instance?

subTopics.name: Androids
subTopics.notes: Artificial men. There are two guises for these creations (sometimes found in the same creature): Frankenstein and Pinnochio.

subTopics.name: Ansible
subTopics.notes: A device that allows instantaneous communication, regardless of distance. Useful for interstellar societies and travellers.

subTopics.name: Anti- and artificial gravity
subTopics.notes: Realistic stories use centripetal force. More fantastic stories assume advanced physics. May be a propulsion system or just a handy gizmo. Prolonged weightlessness is known to cause medical problems.

subTopics.name: Artificial Intelligence
subTopics.notes: See 'robots', 'nanotechnology', 'cyberspace', 'virtual reality.' Assumed as a given in many other SF milieus.

subTopics.name: Behavioral modification
subTopics.notes: By various means (drugs, rays, hypnosis, etc.)  Often used to show the dark side of science.

subTopics.name: Clones
subTopics.notes: Asexually reproduced offspring whose DNA is identical to the 'parent.'  Often represented as twin of parent, ignoring age differences.

subTopics.name: Cyberspace
subTopics.notes: A shared, consensual virtual reality. A computer generated world where people can meet and interact.

subTopics.name: Cyborgs
subTopics.notes: Short for 'cybernetic organism', a hybrid between man and machine. These can range from simple prosthetics to human brains wired into computers or spaceships.

subTopics.name: Exponential machines
subTopics.notes: For large-scale projects, machines could self-replicate- build copies of themselves. For REALLY big projects,  Such as making artificial planets, you would make machines to make machines to make machines.

subTopics.name: Galactic civilizations
subTopics.notes: Used as settings for many SF stories. May be all human, or contain humans and aliens. Often modelled after historical empires. Often used to illustrate social problems and conflicts.

subTopics.name: Gene therapy
subTopics.notes: Like all technology, a two-sided sword. Can be used to cure many diseases, but could also be used for cosmetic purposes, or to create 'genetically superior' people.

subTopics.name: Ghost in the machine
subTopics.notes: With advanced computers and artificial intelligence, it might be possible to 'encode' people, living or dead, into software which acts just as the person would under given circumstances.

subTopics.name: If This Goes On...
subTopics.notes: Extrapolates a present-day situation to its ultimate conclusion. Takes place in the near future. Focuses on a single phenomenon or social issue. Generally a cautionary tale.

subTopics.name: Immortality
subTopics.notes: SF stories have supposed various methods, including assorted medical procedures, gene therapy (a 'death' or clock gene is replaced), nanotechnology cell repairing devices, etc.

subTopics.name: Invisibility
subTopics.notes: Methods used in SF stories have involved chemicals or rays which alter the refractive index, bending light around the object, and 'smart camouflage.'

subTopics.name: Interplanetary travel
subTopics.notes: Often near-future stories. The planets are often viewed in SF as stepping stones to interstellar travel. May also be the SF equivalent of the wild west- the frontier.

subTopics.name: Journey to a strange land
subTopics.notes: Uses the quest or trek story format to describe a SF setting. The setting may be an alien planet, our world in the distant future, a parallel world or time, a fantasy world, etc.. In any case the focus is on the fantastic landscape.

subTopics.name: Interstellar travel
subTopics.notes: The big problem is the incredible distances involved. Various SF strategies are used to get around this: suspended animation, multi-generational ships, and various 'faster than light' propulsion ideas.

subTopics.name: Life extension
subTopics.notes: See 'immortality.'

subTopics.name: Matter transmission
subTopics.notes: Teleportation by transporting matter from one place to another. This is often represented as converting the matter to energy, transmitting the energy, and reversing the process at the other end.

subTopics.name: Multi-generational spaceships
subTopics.notes: Also called slowships. In order to travel interstellar distances at a fraction of lightspeed, the ships must travel for very long times. Entire generations of crew members would be born and die on these voyages.

subTopics.name: Nanotechnology
subTopics.notes: Machines, computers, etc., which are built and operate at nanometer scales. These might construct objects literally an atom or molecule at a time, or might be used to repair individual cells.

subTopics.name: New life forms from gene splicing
subTopics.notes: By transferring genes from one species into the chromosomes of another, new organisms (or modified humans) can be created. Often used with the 'Metamorphosis' master plot.

subTopics.name: New discovery
subTopics.notes: A new invention or discovery is postulated. The story then details the effect the discovery will have on the characters.

subTopics.name: New power sources
subTopics.notes: SF technologies need a lot of energy. Fission, fusion, large-scale solar, or new and imaginary power sources will provide it. Energy shortages and byproducts of energy production can be story problems.

subTopics.name: Parallel Universes
subTopics.notes: Different possible universes branch off from every point in time, so that there is a universe with every possible outcome for every event. This leads to an infinite number of possible worlds, side by side.

subTopics.name: Robots
subTopics.notes: Aspects include labor and production (Can work be eliminated? Can hunger and want?)  Also a bigger question: What does it mean to be human?

subTopics.name: Scientific problem story
subTopics.notes: The protagonist is confronted with a difficult scientific problem which requires great ingenuity to solve.

subTopics.name: Space habitats
subTopics.notes: Large populations will be born, live, and die in space colonies or habitats. Problems will include power and food production, and cultural clashes with planet dwellers.

subTopics.name: Suspended animation
subTopics.notes: Slowing down life processes, often by cryogenic freezing, in order to extend lifespan. Often used in SF for space travel (see 'multi-generational spaceships') or for one-way time travel.

subTopics.name: Time travel
subTopics.notes: May use a time machine simply as a device for voyaging to the past or future, or may play with time paradoxes.

subTopics.name: Virtual reality
subTopics.notes: An illusion of reality created by a computer. The user may wear goggles or headgear on which are projected computer images; more 'advanced' technology might plug the computer right into the brain. See 'cyberspace.'

scenes.name: Adventure
scenes.notes:
Adventures start with the protagonist leaving the normal world
of his home because of some motivating incident. This should
happen quickly.
The story question is usually simple: Will she find a husband?
Will he find his missing father?  Often adventure stories
will include elements of romance- which is always an adventure.
The adventures that make up an adventure story are the
complications of the middle story. It's essential to move
around a lot in these tales, but each incident must still
be plausible and follow from the previous one.
The complications must be complications, and not just
postcards from far-away places. The protagonist's goal should
still drive the plot.
Research is important in adventure plots; the more exotic
the locales and people encountered, the more the need to
look and sound authentic.
The resolution phase must answer the story question posed
in the opening. But just as the story problem itself is often
uncomplicated, so is there no need for complicated resolutions.
In adventure stories, it's the journey itself that's important.

masterPlots.name: Adventure
masterPlots.notes:
The Adventure story is similar to the Quest, but instead of
focusing on the person making the journey, the focus is
on the journey itself. Adventure stories should be full of
of strange settings, characters, and situations- of
vicarious thrills. Adventure is never found at home, or
if it is, home turns out to be a stranger place than first imagined.
The protagonist must seek adventure, or accept it when it's
thrust upon him. Character growth is not key to this masterplot;
what's important is what happens next.

scenes.name: Ascension
scenes.notes:
The force which drives the protagonist, such as ego or ambition,
molds the events of the story: nothing and no one can stand in
her way. But achieving her external goals is not enough; if
the protagonist doesn't tame her demons, they will overwhelm
her.

scenes.name: Descent
scenes.notes:
The forces which motivate the protagonist, such as ego, ambition,
or aggression, aren't changed by character growth and development.
They ultimately serve as the protagonist's undoing. These are
tragedies, stories with unhappy endings. The protagonist is
either lost, or evil, but either way, comes to a bad end.
The failure is at the moment of crisis.

scenes.name: Rise and Fall
scenes.notes:
The story may combine both Ascension and Descent. The
protagonist's drive and determination seemingly give her
the goals she seeks, but the very traits which put her goals
in her grasp also lead to her destruction, because unless
they're controlled, the continue to burn.

masterPlots.name: Ascent/Descent
masterPlots.notes:
These are stories of the protagonist's rise to power.
They're character based, and
the protagonist must be larger than life. She is at odds
with her environment, and wants to change it. Character
traits such as ambition drive these stories.
Ascent may also lead to Descent, unless the protagonist
grows and changes.

scenes.name: Discovery
scenes.notes:
These are character-driven plots, and the protagonist must learn
something about himself, about who he is and what matters to him.
This is a common plot in children's literature; all coming-of-age
stories are Discovery plots.
In Discovery stories, it's important to allow the reader to
discover for himself what it is the protagonist has learned.
Avoid the urge to preach.
Often the protagonist doesn't want to make the discovery.
He may think his life is fine the way it is, or the discovery
may be a painful one (often Discovery means facing something we've
known all along.)
The opening story shows the protagonist prior to the
discovery, but sets the forces in motion which lead to it.
In the middle story the protagonist is forced to confront the
thing about himself that he needs to learn.
The final act begins with his learning the lesson. The
conclusion may either show that he's made the discovery
by some token action, or suggest his resolve to act
differently (based on what he's learned) in the future.

masterPlots.name: Discovery
masterPlots.notes:
The Discovery story is character based, and centers on a person's
need to understand herself. Typically events force a change
upon the protagonist, whose attempts to return to the old self.
When the attempts fail, she undergoes a revelation and achieves
greater self awareness.

scenes.name: Escape
scenes.notes:
Escape plots differ from rescue plots largely in viewpoint;
the victim perpetrates his own escape, rather than waiting to
to be rescued. As such, he's the protagonist.
The opening establishes the need for escape, by showing the
imprisonment. The victim may be guilty or innocent, but if he's
guilty, either the imprisonment will be shown to be
unjustly harsh, or the story will be a test of wills between
a strong jailor and the equally strong prisoner. The story
question is simple: will he escape?
If there is an attempt to escape in the opening phase, it's
feeble and is either thwarted or the victim's easily recaptured.
Escape should be shown to not be easy.
The middle story deals with planning to escape. The
complications are things which thwart these plans.
The resolution phase is the escape itself. Normally the plans
from the second phase fall apart, and things are out of control.
This is the most physically active phase of the story.

masterPlots.name: Escape
masterPlots.notes:
The protagonist is literally trapped, and wants out. Escape is similar
to the Rescue masterplot, but in this plot the victim is the
center of the action, and works
to free himself. Often (but not always) the victim is unfairly
imprisoned. Justly punished or not, the focus of Escape is on the
escape attempt itself.

scenes.name: Forbidden Love
scenes.notes:
The forbidden love may be a case of adultery, a homosexual
affair, incest, age differences or some other type of proscribed
romance. In any case, there must be some social force against
the liaison. The lovers must ignore this social pressure.
The opening phase defines the forbidden relationship
as to what law or convention is violated, and how the various
parties- the lovers and those around them- react to the outrage.
The middle story focuses on the results of breaking convention.
Social forces exert pressure on the lovers and cause problems
for them which may start to break them apart. The complications
must stem directly from the love affair.
The ending takes the affair to its conclusion. Many of the
endings are unhappy, with the lovers separated, dead, or
abandoned.

masterPlots.name: Forbidden Love
masterPlots.notes:
Love is a powerful emotion, but not all love is acceptable to society.
When lovers are confronted with social strictures for the
sake of their love, strong stories can result. The story may
reinforce the taboos as to when and where love is proper. Most
impossible loves end in tragedy. Or the story may show that love
can overcome any obstacle.
Forbidden love can center around any unconventional behavior,
with adultery the most common example.

scenes.name: Love
scenes.notes:
Unlike Forbidden Love, the lovers in a love plot will normally
have a happy ending. But complications must stand between them,
and it must take dedication and perseverance to come to that
happy ending.
The characters of the lovers should be defined to provide
some built-in conflict. They might be from different sides of
the tracks, have different external goals, be physically
different, have differing degrees of education, come from
different cultural groups, etc.
Normally one of the characters will be more aggressive about
the romance, and the other more passive. The role of aggressor
can change in  mid-romance.
The middle story consists of the obstacles to love. There
are only so many of these, so the characters themselves, and
the emotions themselves, are more important, and must be
stressed.
The ending depends on the characters. If they are worthy,
and have endured the obstacles to romance well enough, they
should persevere. But a happy ending forced on the wrong
characters won't work.

masterPlots.name: Love
masterPlots.notes:
True love is hard to find, and harder to hold on to.
The obstacles which
can keep lovers apart are the grist for this masterplot's mill.
The obstacle may be some incompatibility between the lovers,
a misunderstanding or situation that keeps them from consummating
their affair, or it may be a rival suitor. Although the obstacles
to love are the essence of the plot, the real key to Love stories
is the lovers; the chemistry must be right.
Not all Love stories have happy endings.

scenes.name: Metamorphosis
scenes.notes:
The changeling is usually the protagonist. His story is the
attempt to change back to human form, and the story question
is whether or not he will succeed. If the transformation is
caused by evil, the protagonist must have a chance at redemption.
If the changeling is cast as the antagonist, there's little
chance of redemption, but the curse may be ended by his death
(which he may long for.)
The story question is then whether or not he will be defeated
and destroyed.
The story is largely concerned with the nature of the metamorph,
with his character. The transformation is symbolic, and
what he changes into is important for what it represents.
The transformation may have taken place earlier, but the story is
about the journey back to humanity, and it starts near the
beginning of the journey.
The opening phase establishes the transformation itself. The
metamorphosis is usually the result of a curse of some sort.
Often the protagonist doesn't initially understand what's
happened to him.
The middle story concentrates on the struggle to return to
human form. The opposition to that return is the antagonist,
who is also a force for change, destroying the status quo of
the curse (otherwise the changeling might stay transformed.)
At the story opening the protagonist and antagonist are far
apart, but in the middle story they move toward one another.
Whether the changeling returns to human form or is destroyed,
part of the story is the increased understanding of his
transformation.
The resolution either shows the changeling returned to his
original state or killed.

masterPlots.name: Metamorphosis
masterPlots.notes:
Metamorphosis is a change in form or appearance. The change is
from animal or monster to human, or vice versa,
usually as a result of a curse. Metamorphosis connects
us with the animal side of our natures, and
with the multidimensional side of our personalities. The changeling
seeks to be whole and human; the cure is usually love.

scenes.name: Quest
scenes.notes:
The quest plot begins by showing the start of the odyssey.
The journey usually begins at home, and the story's
opening shows the protagonist at home.
An event, or some inner longing, compels the protagonist to action.
But those first tentative steps, aren't enough.
The protagonist must be irrevocably committed to the quest.
The first incident on the quest should serve to remove all choices
about going back. Any doubts are eliminated. At the beginning,
the protagonist may have had only a vague notion of what he
wants to do. This first incident will give him a specific idea of
what he wants to accomplish. The character's initial motivation
should now be even stronger.
The protagonist may receive assistance in the form of travelling
companions or a character offering support and guidance- a mentor.
Both of these types of allies are usually brought into the story
late in the first act.
The hero must be shown to be worthy of winning the goal. Only
serious hurdles will test your protagonist sufficiently to change him,
and in a quest plot, the protagonist must change for the better or worse.
All quests are ultimately inner journeys, and the new awareness must be
born in him as a result of the conflict.
As with Adventure plots, the quest contains built-in movement.
The heroine must go after the prize she seeks; it won't come to
her. This offers opportunities for a wide range of settings.
The protagonist should move freely, and the middle story is where
this movement is played out.
There are three possible outcomes for quests: the protagonist
achieves his goal, he fails to achieve it, or he abandons the
quest. But since the Quest is really an inner journey, the
outcome must stem from the change which occurs in the protagonist's
nature as a result of the journey.

masterPlots.name: Quest
masterPlots.notes:
The Quest plot is the protagonist's search
for an object. It may be a person,
a place (Shangrila), or a tangible
or intangible thing (gold, immortality.)
The object of the search is perceived
by the protagonist as vitally important.
He is shaped by the quest and his success or
failure in obtaining the object.

scenes.name: Pursuit
scenes.notes:
The opening establishes who's chasing who, which one is
the protagonist, and what's at stake if caught (prison, death,
etc.)  As always, the contest should be balanced, so there's
a real chance of either escape or getting caught. Some motivating
incident gets the chase started.
The middle story is the chase itself. Complications, setbacks,
and reversals are the essence of the chase story. Pursuit
plots rely on quick action and lots of it. The action must be
unpredictable and keep the audience off balance. Confine the
characters to limited territory, such as a ship, a building,
or a train, to cut off escape routes and heighten tension.
The ending resolves the pursuit in one of two ways: capture
or escape and freedom.

masterPlots.name: Pursuit
masterPlots.notes:
There is nothing complicated about Pursuit. The pursuer chases
the pursued. All that's needed to get this plot rolling are
these two character roles, the reason for
the pursuit, and something at stake.
The good guy can chase the
bad, or vice versa. The stakes should be suitably high.
Most horror stories are based upon
Pursuit. The story can be told from either perspective,
the pursuer or the one being chased. The plot depends
heavily on physical action.

scenes.name: Rescue
scenes.notes:
The common motivation for the rescuer is love for the victim.
The story line follows the hero in pursuit of the villain. This
frequently takes him to unfamiliar places, such as the villain's
lair.
The opening deals with the issue of separation. The victim
is abducted or placed in jeopardy. The rescuer learns of the
situation and makes pans for pursuit.
The middle story is the pursuit itself. As with pursuit
stories, the goal is to put as many unsuspected twists and
obstacles in the way of the rescuer as possible. This is the
villain's role.
The resolution phase involves confrontation between the
rescuer and the antagonist. This is followed by the reunion
of the rescuer with the victim.

masterPlots.name: Rescue
masterPlots.notes:
Rescue requires three roles: the rescuer (who is the protagonist),
the victim, and the antagonist. Rescue is based upon action rather
than the characters themselves; it's the roles that matter. The focus
is on the protagonist's rescue attempt, and the villain's efforts to
foil it.

scenes.name: Revenge
scenes.notes:
Revenge plots deal not only with the revenge itself, but with
the protagonist's motives for revenge.
The story opens with an outrage, real or imagined. Normal forms
of recourse, such as the law, must be shown as ineffective. The
protagonist has to take matters in his own hands, but the
regular channels should be given a chance first.
The middle story has the protagonist making plans and pursuing
the antagonist. If there is only one antagonist, the plans
and chase get the focus. If the antagonist is powerful and has
allies or henchmen, the protagonist may confront them on his
way to the final confrontation with the antagonist.
The resolution has the protagonist either abandoning his revenge,
or taking it. In the later case the antagonist should be shown
as still worth taking revenge against. The hero's actions should
equal, but not exceed, the offense: an eye for an eye.

masterPlots.name: Revenge
masterPlots.notes:
The Revenge masterplot is about a protagonist who
is forced to take matters into his own hands when
the law doesn't punish a transgression. The nature of
the victim and the crime must make us
cry for rough justice. The story proceeds as
the protagonist attempts to extract retribution equal to
the offense.

scenes.name: Mystery
scenes.notes:
Because the mystery story is largely a challenge to the
Reader to solve the problem, the heart of the story is the
problem: it must be a puzzle, whose solution is not obvious. As
the protagonist struggles to solve the problem, so should the
audience.
It's necessary to play fairly with the readers; they must
be given a fair chance to solve the mystery. This means that
the story must contain clues which allow the solution. It's
all right to misdirect the protagonist and reader, with false
trails and ambiguous clues, but the solution must be in sight,
and you must play fairly.
The protagonist is the reader's agent in these stories; he
must ask the questions that the reader needs asked in order
to solicit the clues. The protagonist is therefore usually
observant and thoughtful.
The opening phase must present the mystery to be solved.
The protagonist's motive for solving the crime should also
be presented. Many mysteries open with the crime itself.
The middle story consists of searching for clues. The
clues should not be too obvious; the perfect clue is like
the purloined letter in Poe's story:  there all the time, in
plain sight.
The resolution involves solving the riddle. The answer must
fit the clues, and explain things. Often solving the riddle
can segue into a more physical plot, such as a chase or pursuit.
But the action is secondary to the mystery.

masterPlots.name: Mystery
masterPlots.notes:
The Mystery revolves around a problem that needs a solution. The
reader is challenged to solve the puzzle. The
events of the story serve two purposes; they move the story
along, but they also are clues which must be interpreted
to help to solve the mystery. The Mystery story succeeds
when it gives the reader a fair chance to find the solution,
but fails when the clues are too obvious or the answer is too
easy to unearth. Mystery is a game, and you must play
by the rules. In this masterplot, the every event must have a reason,
every effect, a cause.

scenes.name: Rivalry
scenes.notes:
The opening phase establishes the protagonist and antagonist
as two equally powerful characters, who are after the same goal.
Each character's relative weakness must be offset by a corresponding
strength: if one is faster, the other should be smarter.
The motives of the rivalry should also be revealed.
The middles story is the clash of equal forces. The contest
should very much be in doubt, with first one side getting the
upper hand, then the other. Frequently the clash of wills
leads to disadvantage for the protagonist, who slowly climbs
back to a position of roughly equal power before the climax.
The resolution is determined by the relative moral positions
of the characters. The antagonist will often cross the line
into immoral or reprehensible conduct during the middle story;
that point determines the winner.
The resolution is the final confrontation between the two
rivals.

masterPlots.name: Rivalry
masterPlots.notes:
Rivalry exists whenever adversaries compete for the same
goal, be it wealth, love, or power. The
outcome must be in doubt, so the adversaries should be
evenly matched; if they're not, it's
the Underdog plot. While the story may be of conflict
between good and evil, it may equally
be between two worthy characters. Whatever the goal,
the struggle itself is the heart of Rivalry.

scenes.name: Sacrifice
scenes.notes:
The sacrifice story explores the character who makes the sacrifice.
As such this is a 'plot of the head', and the character is more
important than the action.
The story opening should show the protagonist as unlikely to
to make the sacrifice; the sacrifice is ultimately a result
of character growth during the story. If the decision is too
easy there's no story. At the same time, the protagonist must
contain traits that make the sacrifice believable. This often
requires back story to explain the inner conflict.
The opening presents the two sides of the sacrifice as having
great meaning to the protagonist. The price of the sacrifice
must be high, but the value of the thing sacrificed for must
also be high.
The middle story must present the protagonist with a complication
which makes the choice, but not the outcome, inevitable. There
should be no easy way out of the dilemma: either the protagonist
avoids the sacrifice, but looses the prize, or makes the sacrifice,
and pays for it.
The resolution focuses on the sacrifice itself, but, more
importantly, on the cost of the sacrifice. The climax should
hang in the balance. But once the choice is made, the story
turns its attention to what the result of the sacrifice is.
Show whether the sacrifice has the desired effect, and show
how the affects the protagonist (the cost.)

masterPlots.name: Sacrifice
masterPlots.notes:
Sacrifice stories are based upon something we instinctively
know is true: things of great value
are obtained only at great price. The thing of value
may be love, honor, or the greater good
of mankind. The price may be life, or the giving up
of a cherished belief or value, but whatever
is sacrificed, it must matter greatly to the protagonist.
In Sacrifice stories the protagonist
must have a choice, an easy way out or the difficult
sacrifice. The story centers around this choice
and explores the protagonist's character under stress.

scenes.name: Temptation
scenes.notes:
In a temptation plot the antagonist can be either the
protagonist himself (man against man), or can be external. If
external, the antagonist/tempter is a symbol; the struggle is
still within the protagonist, of good vs. evil, right vs. wrong.
The opening should present the protagonist and his proposed
transgression. What is the temptation he may give into?  What
are its rewards?  What's the cost of yielding to temptation?
The story question is 'will the protagonist yield to temptation?'
Presenting the story problem is presenting the two sides of
the choice.
The middle story will begin when the protagonist yields to the
temptation. You may want to show the sweet side of giving in,
but it's only temporary satisfaction.
Temptation as sin (error) presents itself. The sweet side
turns bitter, and the costly nature of the decision begins
to be evident. This is the major complication. The protagonist
will try to deny and evade the punishment (further complications),
but to no avail.
The resolution has two possible outcomes. The negative
outcome is tragic; the protagonist can't confess her sin, and
the punishment is final. The positive outcome has the
protagonist, at the climax, confess and ask forgiveness. The
result is the happy ending: the forgiveness is granted, and
joy is restored.

masterPlots.name: Temptation
masterPlots.notes:
Temptation is conflict: the devil on one shoulder
battling the angel on the other. This
character-based masterplot tells the story of the
price of yielding to temptation. Although the
antagonist/tempter may appear to be another person,
the real adversary is the protagonist's bad side,
the part that yields to temptation. The story's
resolution stems from the protagonist's guilt, anger,
or remorse over giving in, and ends in atonement and forgiveness.

scenes.name: Transformation
scenes.notes:
The transformation masterplot is a 'plot of the head', stressing
character rather than action.
The inciting incident is the key to the transformation plot's
opening phase. The incident should be big enough to start a
life-changing process in the protagonist:  the emergence from
childhood to adulthood, the death of a loved one, war, etc.
The first act ends as the transforming incident begins to
work on the character of the protagonist and cause change.
The middle story shows the transformation affecting the
protagonist's perceptions. This often requires self-examination
and inward turning, so close viewpoints are normal for these
stories.
The resolution clarifies the change that the initial incident
started. This usually requires another external event, to
which the protagonist can react to show how he's changed. In
many stories, the 'lesson' of this final reaction is different
than the initial transformation suggests.

masterPlots.name: Transformation
masterPlots.notes:
In Transformation, the protagonist undergoes change,
and is a different person at the end of the story than at
she was at the beginning. The change may be from
one stage of development to another, such as 'coming
of age' stories. The change may begin with a
transforming experience such
as a religious conversion, war, the death of a
loved one, or the birth of a child. Or it may come from
the protagonist being made aware of some aspect of
her personality or background which is unexpected and
unwanted. Transformation stories end with the protagonist learning
the lesson of the change, or with an incident which
shows the complete transformation.

scenes.name: Underdog
scenes.notes:
In many underdog stories, the antagonist is society or the
situation or nature- some juggernaut of opposing force.
The protagonist should be a simple character, and is often
less intelligent or more humble than the intended audience.
His strength is his tenacity and willingness to struggle.
The opening should put the protagonist at a disadvantage. Show
him loosing power and being oppressed or suppressed by the
antagonist. The opening act should end by resistance, however,
with the protagonist initiating some action to prevail.
The middle story begins with the outcome of the protagonist
first effort to assert himself. At first it may appear to
succeed, but the gain is offset by a setback. Subsequent
attempts to gain the upper hand also fail. But after each
failure the protagonist tries again.
The resolution begins with the protagonist approaching a
parity with the antagonist, so that for the first time, the
outcome is in doubt. The protagonist now actively confronts
the antagonist in a showdown.

masterPlots.name: Underdog
masterPlots.notes:
This plot is similar to Rivalry. But in Rivalry the
two adversaries are evenly pitted (it's a fair contest.)
There's nothing fair about Underdog stories. The
protagonist faces a seemingly unstoppable opponent. These plots
attract readers and viewers because we are all
underdogs at one time or another, and have faced
overpowering circumstances.
The Underdog hero is us, working out our fantasies.

scenes.name: Immoderation
scenes.notes:
The immoderation plot starts with a flawed trait in the
character of the protagonist. The character defect is what leads
him to immoderation. This is a 'plot of the head', and the
character development is especially important.
The opening shows the character before the decline, in order
to showcase the changes. The 'inciting incident' is may be
a circumstance which forces the character to act differently.
The middle story shows the decline itself. The decline
traces the ascendancy of the flawed trait over other aspects
of the character. The loss of control should be gradual.
Focus on the emotions, but also keep the
protagonist as sympathetic as possible. His decline has to be
felt as tragedy.
The third act begins at the point where the protagonist has
lost control, and things can't get worse. There are two
possible outcomes. The protagonist must either move toward
recovery and redemption, or must be utterly destroyed.
A 'precipitating incident' may be the pivot on which the
resolution changes. If the protagonist moves toward
redemption, this is a 'came to realize' event, and the incident
shows the character how far he's declined. If the ending
is tragic, the protagonist should take some unrecoverable
action such as murder or suicide.

masterPlots.name: Immoderation
masterPlots.notes:
This plot deals with a flawed but sympathetic person
who's been pushed to the edge, either by madness or
by events. Placed under
extreme circumstances, the wild animal which is
inside each of us emerges, and the decline to  the
pit begins. The story can
end on an upbeat note, with the protagonist moving
back toward normalcy, or in tragedy.

A Family at War (Emnity of Kinsmen).name: A Family at War (Emnity of Kinsmen)

Supplication.notes: Someone who needs help, usually due to the antagonist. Fillin the why, who, and how it is resolved.
Supplication.name: Supplication

Rivalry of Kinsman.notes: Sibling rivalry, or rivalry between family members. The object of the rivalrychooses or is given to the preferred kinsman.
Rivalry of Kinsman.name: Rivalry of Kinsman

Dream State.notes: In Figgis' list but not Polti's. The Dream State is a surreal sitation or eventand the rules of suspension of disbelief may be stretched. We understand thatthe situation is other-worldly and the audience accepts the part of the dreamer.
Dream State.name: Dream State

Obstacles to Love.notes: Lovers overcoming the obstacles, or the tragedy of failing to overcome.Love is not just the joining of individuals, but of their families orassociated groups, which can create conflicts.
Obstacles to Love.name: Obstacles to Love

Abduction.notes: Kidnapping and negotiation. This is sometimes teamed with a rescue (Deliverance).
Abduction.name: Abduction

Loss of a Loved One.notes: Best used as a motivation for, or result of another plot strand.
Loss of a Loved One.name: Loss of a Loved One

Recovery of a Lost One.notes: Similar to Deliverance, but without necessarily requiring rescue.
Recovery of a Lost One.name: Recovery of a Lost One

Deliverance.notes: Similar to Supplication, but with the emphasis on rescuing another person rather than seeking assistance.
Deliverance.name: Deliverance

Fatal Imprudence (The Gambler).notes: A character's naivete has drastic consequences.
Fatal Imprudence (The Gambler).name: Fatal Imprudence (The Gambler)

Conflicts with Power.notes: Anything from a character up against a former mentor, to a supposedly weaker character using other abilities to defeat, or attempt to defeat, a stronger rival.
Conflicts with Power.name: Conflicts with Power

Pursuit.notes: The fugitive flees punishment for a misunderstood conflict.
Pursuit.name: Pursuit

Remorse.notes: Regret. Resolution usually requires another situation. An internal 'man against himself' problem, remorse centes on motivation.
Remorse.name: Remorse

The Enigma.notes: A mystery or mysterious person, situation, or object. Theinterrogator poses the problem to the seeker. Often an introductionto another situation or subplot.
The Enigma.name: The Enigma

Betrayal of Love (Adultery).notes: Adultery may be treated as a psychological problem, centered on theprotagonists, or may lead to another plot situation.
Betrayal of Love (Adultery).name: Betrayal of Love (Adultery)

roles: The disaster itself, or a victorious enemy
Disaster.notes: Anticipation before or survival after a natural or human-inflicted disaster.
Disaster.name: Disaster

Can be used for bothcomedic or tragic effect. Connects with many other situations as either setupor payoff.
Coincidence.name: Coincidence

This can lead to numerous situationsand complications. 'Loved one' can be expanded to include members of aclan or group, co-workers, etc.

Madness.notes: The madness might claim a victim, or explore the line between sanity and insanity.

Self-Sacrifice for Idealism.notes: The conflict is internal (man vs. himself.)
Self-Sacrifice for Idealism.name: Self-Sacrifice for Idealism
